source.8d752e55:
# using helper functions that we created in order grab count of unique languages and sort them w.r.t keys for better plotting
langworked_counts = count_dict("LanguageWantToWorkWith")
# sorting w.r.t to values and converting values to percentage
langworked_counts = sort_to_per(langworked_counts)

# plotting a bar graph as it will help us see what % of programmers want to work with which language
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(15,15))
ax = sns.barplot(x=list(langworked_counts.values()), y=list(langworked_counts.keys()), palette="muted", orient="h");
ax.bar_label(ax.containers[0])
ax.set_title("Languages want to be used by programmers")
ax.set_xlabel("% of programmers")
ax.set_ylabel("Language");

def cal_sentiment(x):
    sentence = x 
    vs = analyzer.polarity_scores(sentence)
    return vs["pos"]

source.f00e4a6d:
## Inferences and Conclusion

Through this analysis we were able to see that the total of 40 questions were asked in this year's survey. Most of the programmers who were participated in the survey were from United States, India, Germany, UK, Canada and France. The age range of the most of the programmers around the world is 25-34 years old. Lot of the programmers started coding when they were 11-17 yrs old. Most of the developers seems to be working in the field of `web and app development`. Since lot of them are in the field of web development it can be seen that the popular languages in which they are working are `JavaScript` and `HTML/CSS`. After them we also a Python as a popular language too. Coming to databases, it was found out that `MySQL` and `PostgreSQL` are commonly used Databases by developers. Also tools like `Git` and `Docker` are popular among the developers.
Now coming to mental health, as per the responses given by programmers it was very clear that lot of the programmers doesn't seem to be having a very good mental health conditions. So it is request from my side for all my developer friends to take care of your mental health 🙏

source.b1391657:
## Stack Overflow Annual Developer Survey 2021

![stackoverflow_icon](https://miro.medium.com/max/1200/0*UEtwA2ask7vQYW06.png) 

 
The Stackoverflow developer survey is an annual survey that gathers data and insights by asking developers across wide demography, geography, and professional positions questions concerning their preference in technologies, tools, and platforms in the software development field. 
In this project, we will be exploring the survey conducted in 2021 and will try to gather some useful insights and will try to answer some questions which comes to our mind.

**The Dataset** which we will be using can be found here at official Stack Overflow's website : https://info.stackoverflowsolutions.com/rs/719-EMH-566/images/stack-overflow-developer-survey-2021.zip   but it will be a bit inefficient to first download the .zip file then extract it. 

So we will be using the same dataset which is available on kaggle : https://www.kaggle.com/ruchi798/stack-overflow-annual-developer-survey-2021

source.b7a573db: Seems like we only have a one integer column which is "ResponseId" and all other columns are of type "object" which is a generic datatype which pandas uses when it is not able to identify what type of data is present in column but most of the time we can interpret it as a "string" datatype.
source.48862419:
Here's just a snapshot of what I understood about what information each column in representing:

* qid: string, unique question ID
* qname: string, (Not understood)
* question: string, the question asked
* force_resp: bool, compulsory to answer
* type: string, (Not understood)
* selector: string, (Not understood)

And it can also be noted that Non-null count is same as the total number of entries (rows) present in our dataset. Therefore, no missing values are present

source.7885b083:
Installing Vader library ...
Valence aware dictionary for sentiment reasoning (VADER) is popular rule-based sentiment analyzer. 

It uses a list of lexical features (e.g. word) which are labeled as positive or negative according to their semantic orientation to calculate the text sentiment.   

Vader sentiment returns the probability of a given input sentence to be 

Positive, negative, and neutral.
